title.narrative: Promoting inclusive agribusiness in La Palma, Pinar del Río

participating-org.narrative: International Centre for development oriented Research in Agriculture
International Centre for development oriented Research in Agriculture

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

title.narrative: Project photo
Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities . Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the grant award letter, the dates for submission of the annual reports are mentioned. In case of a three-year project, between 5-7 reports are obligatory. The first report (0) is a very short report which focuses on specific conditions and/or recommendations in the grant. There is no need to report on progress in achieving outputs and outcomes, which is done in the first annual report. As annex to the report 0, the consortium agreements between the partners should be submitted. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative: In this section (maximum 1000 words), please provide a global overview of the project progress **per output**. To what extent have they been achieved? Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

actual.value:
The TMT provided knowledge and skills to the Agricultural Teaching and Research Division (ADSA) of Pinar del Río University.
Specifically the TMT:
a. Strengthened the capacity of technical staff to support the development of sustainable businesses, adding value to local products and services.
b. Promoted effective alliances/partnerships between ADSA staff, banks and representatives from the emerging private and cooperative farming sector;
c. Strengthened the business capacities of staff and local entrepreneurs to organise joint initiatives (win-win situations);
d. Incorporated entrepreneurship concept and action learning approach into the learning curriculum of ADSA.
The enabling environment created through the training and the new government policy that promotes the creation of small and medium enterprises now in Cuba, will contribute that the business models collaboratively designed by lecturers and local entrepreneurs could have continuity beyond the training.

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative: In this section (maximum 1000 words), please provide a global overview of the project progress **per output**. To what extent have they been achieved? Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

actual.value:
In the following the business ideas and actions developed by participants are summarised:
1. Sale of bean seeds: Design of a business model that allows the maintenance of a large collection of bean seeds. Participants identified a portfolio of clients and started negotiating for the commercialisation of seeds.
2. Restaurant: With the collaboration of local artists, a participant designed a new restaurant in La Palma Municipality which will offer food from local farmers' farms. Elaboration of an action plan for the opening of the restaurant by March 2022.
3. Organic Fertilisers: Design of a business model to generate income from the treatment of manure produced by local farmers. Elaboration of an action plan for its implementation.
4. Orange dessert: Inspired by the initial success of the Orange sweets, a participant organises the growth of her business. She designs the brand "Delicias Macagua", adjusts her business model and presents an action plan to train raw material suppliers. (
5. Breeding of Cuyes: Creating a favourable environment around the consumption of Cuyes. A social media campaign is planned to promote the consumption of Cuyes.
6. Condiments Maité: Strategy to expand the production of condiments powder. Development of a business plan to supply seeds of the condiment plants to local farmers for further processing in condiment factory.
7. Agrotourism: Inspired by the initial success of a Rural Hostel, a participant has the ambition to promote the growth of her business through the "Guajira" brand in collaboration with an American investor, one of the creators of Airnb, she developed a strategy to attract tourists from the United States to the western region of Cuba and Canada from November 2021.
8. Wine ‘Marcelino’: One participant, has ambitions to expand his wine business promoting a new brand whose ingredients do not depend on government-supplied raw materials. New customers for his most popular wines were identified and an action plan was drawn up to position new wines in the market.
9. Broiler chicken: A commercial agreement was drawn up with new clients interested in distributing chickens in the city of Havana.
10. Bio-fertilisers: Participants proposes the use of a new biological fertiliser to local farmers. For this he designs a field school for local farmers to test the new product. Development of an apprenticeship programme with the farmers to test the new bio-fertiliser.
11. Promotion of the Pardo Cubano rabbit breed: Proposal to increase the production of the Pardo Cubano breed, which is adapted to local conditions, and to train a group of local meat suppliers. To attract new customers, a commercial brand was designed, and an action plan was elaborated involving social networks, radio and local television.
12. Coffee seedlings: Promotion of Robusta coffee beyond the municipality. A business plan was drawn up for the sale of Robusta coffee seedlings and the first customers in Havana were identified.
